EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  6.01
	 
	 
A Better Shelter Scholarship
	 
A Better Shelter Club, founded by Paul Nguyen and Vivek Sharath, has provided graduating seniors an opportunity to apply for “A Better Shelter Scholarship”.  Eligible students were selected based on the following criteria:  students that have faced personal life changing challenges, academic achievement, and submission of an essay describing their future goals and plans to achieve.  Two students were selected and scholarships, each in the amount of $500, will be awarded to:
	 
Ana Maria Valencia, Silver Creek High School
Saba Mahdavi, Silver Creek High School

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Ann Feng-Gagne, Executive Director, Dolinka Group, LLC
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding Demography Services Study
	 
	 
The Board approved and the District contracted for the professional services of Dolinka Group on January 15, 2015, to conduct a Demographic Analysis and Enrollment Projection Study.  The study included an in-depth analysis of enrollment, including birth data, migration rates, and charter school growth; land use, development, and planning; residency and census data along with Geographic Information System (GIS) data and spatial analysis.  The study aimed to examine enrollment trends throughout the District for budgetary planning, as well as current and future building capacity needs.  The District intends to use the study results to inform the current budget and for future facility planning efforts and considerations by the Board and administration.  
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive Demography study as presented.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the Demography study as presented.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance; Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve First Amendment to MOU regarding Facilities Between ESUHSD and Leadership Public Schools, Inc.
	 
Leadership Public Schools, Inc. (“LPS”) operates the Leadership Public Schools-San Jose public charter high school (“LPS-SJ”), which was chartered by the Santa Clara County Board of Education.  The District and Leadership Public Schools, Inc. are parties to an MOU regarding facilities pursuant to which the District provides facilities for LPS-SJ’s in-district students at the W.C. Overfelt campus.  The MOU is for a term of five years and expires on June 30, 2015, except that the MOU, per its terms, shall automatically renew for five years (through June 30, 2020) if the LPS-SJ’s charter is in good standing.  As of this date, the LPS-SJ charter is in good standing with the County Board of Education.
	 
LPS-SJ has experienced declining enrollment and in-district ADA.  On that basis, the District has worked collaboratively with LPS to reduce the total facilities to be provided to LPS pursuant to the MOU from 21 classroom buildings and 2 restroom buildings, currently, to 13 classroom buildings and 1 restroom building on the W.C. Overfelt campus and also to reduce the total fees to be paid by LPS to the District for such facilities from $120,000 annually to $104,659.20 annually.  The attached First Amendment to the MOU addresses and memorializes the reduction in facilities and fees payable.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Per First Amendment, As described above
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees review and approve the proposed First Amendment to MOU regarding facilities between ESUHSD and Leadership Public Schools, Inc. as presented.

Item: 8.05
		 
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Rogelio M. Ruiz, Esq., Legal Counsel
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Final Proposition 39 Facilities Offer and Facilities Use Agreement with Alpha: Cindy Avitia Charter High School
		 
		 
On October 31, 2014, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2015-2016 school year from Alpha: Cindy Avita Charter High School.  (“Alpha”).  Pursuant to the Charter Act and Title 5 of the California Code of regulations, section 11969.9, the District timely responded to Alpha’s request for facilities and ADA projections. 
		 
The District and Alpha thereafter entered into collaborative discussions regarding a facilities use agreement for Alpha at W. C. Overfelt High School, but subject to approval by the Board.  A copy of the proposed one year agreement for facilities at W. C. Overfelt High School is attached for Board consideration.
		 
If the Board approves the form of agreement as presented, Administration requests authority to submit to Alpha a final one year facilities agreement substantially in the form presented.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Measures G, E and/or I; Capital Facilities Funds
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To be determined
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the form of Memorandum of Understanding regarding Proposition 39 Facilities Use Agreement 2015-2016 between the District and Alpha: Cindy Avita Charter High School for a one year term and authorize Administration to enter into such agreement in substantially the form presented.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.06
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Adam Kaye, and April Chou, KIPP Bay Area Schools
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding KIPP Bay Area Charter Schools Prop 39 Facilities Ground Lease Proposal
	 
KIPP Bay Area Schools is interested in securing the Board’s support for a ground lease for a portion of 1790 Educational Park Drive, San Jose CA 95133, containing up to 160,000 square feet (estimated area of existing dedicated space, including asphalt area, adjacent parking, and grassy area adjacent to parking).  We anticipate that we will construct a facility of between 45,000 and 60,000 square feet, likely a combination of single story and 2-story buildings including a small gym/multi-purpose center in the area that currently encompasses our KIPP San Jose campus.  Our vision consist of core academic classrooms, which includes science labs, special education rooms, enrichment spaces, cafeteria, media center/library, and a small gymnasium.  In addition, there will be an administration and faculty office, student services and custodial spaces planned. The attached is an overview of KIPP Bay Area Schools and San Jose Collegiate, along with an overview of our intentions and vision for KIPP San Jose Collegiate at Independence High School. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Presentation Only.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  8.08
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
						 
SUBJECT:
 Presentation and/or Discussion regarding City Year
		 
W.C. Overfelt will share with the Board its plan to partner with City Year to provide supplemental academic support.  City Year’s Whole School Whole Child Program model leverages the unique assets of near- peer corps members to deliver research-based whole school supports and student interventions targeting the early warning indicators of poor attendance, unsatisfactory behavior, and course failure in English and math. This portfolio of services supports quality, data-driven instruction, deepens family and community engagement, and contributes to a culture of empowerment, achievement, and service. Corps members deliver these activities throughout the day, from before the first bell through the conclusion of after-school. This provides a continuous, supportive presence throughout the day to build mutually supportive connections between students’ classroom learning and their before- and after-school experiences. 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the City Year presentation.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Associate Superintendent of Human Resources 
					 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:05 p.m. regarding the Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for Contract Reopeners for 2015-2016: From the East Side Union High School District to the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187 
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following contract reopener proposals to the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187, for the 2015-2016 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547, the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its classified employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  
	 
Accordingly, the District proposes the following areas for contract reopeners: total compensation, which includes salary and benefits (Articles 15 and 16); contract language amendments to Articles 14 and 17. The District also has an interest in ensuring that contract language is consistent with current funding formulas; eliminating references to COLA. 
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board sunshine and accept any public comment on the District’s initial proposal for contract reopeners to the California Employees Association, Chapter 187 for 2015-2016.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Frank Biehl, Board Clerk, Pattie Cortese, Board Member, and 
Bud LoMonaco, CBOC Member
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion, Consideration and/or Action Regarding the Selection/Appointment
of Measures G, E, I and Ed-Tech I Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee Members
	 
	 
Pursuant to Section 15278 of the Education Code, the District is obligated to establish a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee (CBOC) in order to satisfy the accountability requirements of Proposition 39 type general obligation bonds. The Committee is required to consist of a minimum of seven (7) members appointed by the Board of Trustees. 
	 
As explained in the terms of Proposition 39, the CBOC is required to have members that meet the criteria listed below:
	 
One (1) member shall be active in a business organization representing the business community located within the District
One (1) member shall be active in a senior citizens’ organization
One (1) member shall be active in a bona fide taxpayers’ organization
One (1) member shall be the parent or guardian of a child enrolled in the district
One (1) member shall be both a parent or guardian of a child enrolled in the District and be active in a parent-teacher organization, such as the Parent-Teacher Association or the School Site Council
Two (2) members of the community at-large
	 
No employees or officials of the District can be appointed to the CBOC.  Also vendors, contractors, or consultants of the District are not allowed to serve as members of the Committee. 
	 
Under the current bylaws of the CBOC, members are allowed to serve three (3) consecutive two (2) year terms. To allow for history and consistency, terms are staggered to avoid all members terming out at the same time.
	 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees appoint the following individuals to serve on the 2015/2016 Measures G, E and I and Ed-Tech I Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee:

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  12.01
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding Summer School Three (3) Year Trend
		 
East Side Union High School District has offered summer school programs to help students recover credits and to advance to higher level courses.  Before the economic downturn, the District offered summer school programs at all of its comprehensive high schools.  Courses were offered as long as there were enough student requests and teachers willing to teach.  The State funded a small number of sections intended to help students accelerate as enrichment.  As the District began to experience budget constraints, the Summer Program was reduced by offering it at half the schools and alternating them every year.  Eventually, the District had to reduce its Summer Program to the bare minimum required for special needs students.  Schools were left to use their site supplemental funds and outside grants to try to offer limited Summer Programs.  As the budget has begun to recover and additional supplemental funds have been available, the District has begun to, once again, offer summer programs at each of the high schools.  Beginning with the summer of 2013, Summer Bridge (incoming freshman) program was offered at each of the high schools. This past summer, the program was expanded to include some credit recovery offerings.  This summer the District will, once again, offer summer programs at each campus.
		  
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To be determined
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
As stipulated by the Board of Trustees

Each program has unique characteristics that support the unique needs of the child and family and each program has different enrollment requirements.

SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of Preliminary Budget for 2015-2016
	 
Attached for your review is a presentation of the 2015-16 Preliminary Budget as recommended. This is the first of three presentations of the Budget to the Governing Board.  The Preliminary Budget is the result of a culmination of budget development activities between the sites, departments, and Superintendent’s Council which provides a basis for the final budget.  The Preliminary Budget Presentation is summarized first by providing an update on the District’s fiscal year ending 2014-15 budget, State budget update, and preliminary assumptions.  The fiscal year 2014-15 budget is presented to provide year end projections for revenues, expenses, and ending fund balance.  After reviewing the fiscal year end 2014-15 summary, major budget assumptions for developing the 2015-16 budget will be discussed including School Services of California Dartboard, enrollment and ADA, and salaries and benefits.  The impact and adjustments based on the Governor’s May Revisions have not been announced yet and will be presented at the first Governing Board Meeting in June.  
	 
The Preliminary Budget Presentation summarizes the projected estimate for general fund revenues and expenses for budget year 2015-16 and for the multi-year through 2017-18 and incorporates all proposed savings, additions and adjustments to the District’s budget.  The presentation concludes with a summary of proposed actions and next steps in the budget process.  The final budget will be presented for budget adoption at the Governing Board’s June 18th meeting.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item: 13.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Vida Branner, Director of Compensation and Classified Employee Relations
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2014/2015-23 to Hire Short-Term Non-Certificated Summer Staff
	 
	 
Although grounds upkeep, District-wide clean-up, and routine IT related work occurs routinely in the District, the District has been unable to keep pace with the level of effort required to meet the needs based on costs considerations and manpower requirements.  In an effort to address these burgeoning needs each year, the District instituted a summer short-term work program.  The District's goal is to make an intense effort to get the routine work caught-up during the summer so that current manpower resources can keep pace with the needs during the school year.  In addition, this work will enhance the aesthetics, cleanliness, safety and security of our school campuses.  This type of work is best done over the summer for ease of access to facilities.  
	 
As a result of an increase in hiring of additional maintenance staff, the District has been able to scale back this program.  In the summer of 2012, the District hired 40 short-term workers, 30 in the summer of 2014, and 23 are being proposed for the summer of 2015.  The budget requirements have also fallen from $182,000 in the summer of 2014 to a proposed $135,000 for this request.  The request for non-certificated short-term summer staff will help ensure that we are able to address these needs in an intense and focused manner. 
	 
Fiscal Impact:
$135,000.00     
	 
Funding Source:
Restricted Maintenance, and General Fund
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2014/2015-23 to Hire Short-Term Non-Certificated Summer Staff.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, André Bell, Assistant Director of Capital Accounting and Purchasing, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Award a Contract for Design-Build Services for the Districtwide Swimming Pool Modernization Project
	 
	 
On March 21, 2013, the Board of Trustees, pursuant to Education Code §17250.20, adopted Resolution 2012/2013-26 to use the design-build delivery method for the Swimming Pool Modernizations Project at James Lick, Piedmont Hills, Mt. Pleasant, Santa Teresa, Silver Creek, W.C. Overfelt and Yerba Buena High Schools (Item 15.03). 
	 
Request for Proposals
The District developed a Request for Proposals (RFP).  The RFP specified that the following selection criteria were to be considered in selecting the DBE whose proposal demonstrated the “best value” to the District, as defined in Education Code §17250.15.  The “best value” basis of evaluation allows the District to select a DBE based on more than price alone, one of the advantages of design-build in comparison to traditional delivery methods.  The first five criteria are required by Education Code §17250.15, the code section under which this design-build project is to be awarded.  The additional criteria, which are critical to the success of the project, were added at the District’s discretion.
	 
Price                                                                   25  points
Technical Expertise                                               5  points
Life Cycle Costs over 25 Years                             5  points
Skilled Labor Force Availability                           10  points
Acceptable Safety Record                                    5  points
Schedule                                                             20 points
Architectural Aesthetics and Design Innovation   9  points
Project Management Plan                                  10  points
Program Requirements                                       11 points
	 
TOTAL (Maximum)                  100 points
	 
The RFP was issued to two Design-Build Entities (DBEs) who were prequalified for this project:  Gonsalves & Stronck Construction, Inc. (G&S) and Strawn Construction Company, Inc. (Strawn).  On February 12, 2014, the District received proposals from both DBEs; both proposals were evaluated and found to be unresponsive.  The District issued a new RFP; on January 31, 2015, we received new and responsive proposals from both prequalified DBEs.  
	 
	 
Proposal Evaluation Summary
District staff and construction management staff from Swinerton Management & Consulting found that while both proposals are responsive to the RFP, Strawn’s proposal provides the best value to the District.  The following summarizes the District’s assessment of the nine selection criteria, which were described in the RFP. 
	 
Price:  Each Design-Build Entity could earn a maximum of twenty (25) points in this category. A maximum of twenty (20) points could be earned for achieving the scope of work within the District’s stipulated budget of $11.3 million.  Another maximum of five (5) points could be earned from the value offered in the unsolicited alternates included in the proposal.
	 
Strawn’s proposal includes 5 new superpools and minor modernizations of 2 existing pools in the stipulated budget, along with an unsolicited alternate to upgrade the 2 minor modernizations to new superpools.  G&S’s proposal includes 3 new superpools and 4 minor modernizations, along with an unsolicited alternate to upgrade the 3 minor modernizations to new superpools.  Each proposal offers various other unsolicited alternates which enhance functionality, improve energy efficiency, lower life cycle costs, and address poor existing conditions and code deficiencies.  Strawn’s proposal in this Price category is superior to G&S’s, as reflected in the score of 22 points for Strawn and 17 points for G&S.
	 
Technical Expertise: Each DBE could earn a maximum score of five (5) points in this category. 
	 
G&S proposes an experienced team of project managers, field superintendents, architects, subcontractors and specialty consultants to design and construct this project, earning them 5 points in this category.  Strawn also proposes an experienced team, but their field superintendents have slightly less experience than those of G&S; for this reason, they earned 4 points in this category.  
	 
Life Cycle Costs: Each DBE could earn a maximum score of five (5) points in this category, by proposing facilities whose sustainable design results in a low life cycle cost as calculated over a twenty-five (25) year period.  The life cycle cost calculation includes the first cost of the project, operating costs, and replacement costs of any systems/components whose service lives do not exceed twenty-five (25) years. 
	 
G&S’s proposal satisfies the program requirement of calculating life cycle costs over a twenty-five year period for the new superpools and the modernized existing pools. The proposal outlines the expected cost to be incurred by the District, not only for design and construction of the pools, but also owning, maintaining and operating them.  G&S earned 5 points in this category.  Strawn’s proposal includes life cycle costs for the new superpools only; for this reason, Strawn earned 3 points.
	 
Skilled Labor Force: Each DBE could earn a maximum of ten (10) points by satisfying the requirements for “skilled labor force availability” as defined in California Education Code Section 17250.10 – 17250.50.  Each was asked to evidence in its Proposal a commitment to furthering these goals:  1) maximizing opportunities for local, small and emerging businesses to compete fairly for work associated with this Project; 2) maximizing opportunities for local workers to be employed on the Project; and 3) incorporating requirements of the District’s Project Labor Agreement.
	 
Strawn’s proposal meets the requirement to ensure a skilled labor force on this project. Their proposal describes how they will utilize a local union workforce and create 7 high school student summer internships, earning them 10 points.  G&S’s proposal similarly commits to using a union workforce and creating summer internships, but with less specificity, earning them 9 points.
	 
Acceptable Safety Record: Each DBE could earn a maximum score of five (5) points in this category.  Three (3) points could be earned by demonstrating an acceptable safety record.  An additional two (2) points could be earned by submitting a superior Project Safety Plan (PSP), evidencing an exceptionally comprehensive Injury & Illness Prevention Plan (IIPP), and having a low Experience Modification Factor rating. 
	 
The primary metric of an acceptable safety record is a contractor’s Experience Modification Rate (EMR), which is a measure of the frequency of accidents and injuries that a contractor has incurred on a historical basis.  G&S’s EMR of .66 is significantly better than the industry average of 1.0, they provided evidence of an IIPP as well as the outline of a PSP; they earned 4 points in this category.  Strawn’s EMR of .83 is also better than industry average, they provided evidence of an IIPP, and their PSP was complete and superior in demonstrating their commitment to a safe campus environment during the construction period for students, staff and construction workers; Strawn earned 5 points in this category.
	 
Schedule: Each DBE could earn a maximum of twenty (20) points by proposing creative scheduling that will reduce the overall length of time of construction, as well as minimize the impact on the sites as a whole. 
	 
Both DBEs proposed aggressive project schedules, and G&S’s proposal even includes several schedule options for consideration.  Strawn’s proposed schedule includes more realistic timelines for Division of the State Architect review of the plans prior to construction, along with written commitment from their swimming pool subcontractor on the aggressive construction schedule, earning Strawn 16 points in this category.  G&S earned 15 points in this category; the evaluation panel was impressed with the flexibility 
offered with the multiple schedule options, which while not required in the RFP, indicates an understanding by G&S’s team of the schedule concerns of various project stakeholders.
	 
Architectural Aesthetics and Design Innovation: Each DBE could earn a maximum of nine (9) points in this category, through the quality of their design solutions as well as the level of innovation reflected in each DBE’s design solution, and its overall approach to constructing the Project. 
	 
Strawn’s proposal provides design narratives, outline specifications, and site plans for each school’s pool.  Their proposed superpool offers the minimum code-required amount of shallow water for physical education and non deep-water safe swimmers.  Their proposal earned Strawn 7 points in this category.  G&S’s proposal provides design narratives and outline specifications, and typical site plans for the various pool options offered within the stipulated sum and as unsolicited alternates.  G&S’s proposed superpool design includes a more gracious shallow water area.  G&S’s proposal earned 6 points in this category.  
	 
Project Management Plan: Each DBE could earn a maximum of ten (10) points by evidencing superiority in their proposed logistics plan, quality assurance/quality control plan, structure of organizational chart, knowledge/skill/ability/experience of key personnel, Owner/Design-Build Entity interaction strategies, and other aspects of project management. 
	 
G&S’s proposal includes information that conveys their plan adequately, which earned them 8 points in this category.  Strawn’s proposal includes the required information, plus additional information that offers a superior understanding of how they plan to interact with stakeholders and their design philosophy for each design discipline, which earned them 9 points in this category.
	 
Program Requirements: Each DBE could earn a maximum of eleven (11) points by proposing design(s) that achieves the District’s aquatic program components. 
	 
Strawn’s proposal of 5 new superpools plus 2 existing pool modernizations within the stipulated budget achieves more aquatic program satisfaction than G&S’s 3+4 proposal.  Strawn earned 8 points in this category, and G&S earned 6 points.
	 
Based on the proposal evaluation criteria described above, the final score for each DBE is as follows:

The RFP specified that following the scoring of each DBE’s proposal, at which time the DBE whose proposal is deemed most responsive to the RFP was determined, and pursuant to Education Code §17250.25(a)(2)(v), the District reserved the right to hold discussions or negotiations with that DBE for the purpose of receiving clarification and/or modification to their proposal, in order to achieve a resulting Best and Final Proposal that could be recommended to the Board of Trustees for contract award.  
	 
Budget Augmentation
Prior to entering into negotiations with Strawn, District administration engaged the Board at the March 5, 2015 meeting to request a budget augmentation that would allow the design and construction of new superpools at all seven school sites affected by the project.  On March 5, 2015, the Board of Trustees augmented the budget in an amount not to exceed $7.2 million (Item 15.01).  In addition, the Board stated that those schools with the desire to increase the size of their swimming pools could do so, using site-directed bond funding allocations.   
	 
Aquatics Programming Needs Assessment at each School Site 
District Facilities staff, Strawn Construction’s design team and Swinerton Management met with each of the Principals, aquatics coaching staff and athletic directors to review the existing and future aquatics activities and program needs.  Based upon these meetings, the aquatic program needs for the seven schools are as follows:  
	 
Physical Education / Swim Instruction 
Competitive Swimming 
Water Polo 
Diving 
	 
All of these aquatic programs could be accommodated with the budgeted superpool size of 6,255 square feet. Five schools (James Lick, Piedmont Hills, Silver Creek, W.C. Overfelt and Yerba Buena) have approved an H-shaped superpool configuration.  Two schools (Mt. Pleasant, Santa Teresa) have larger competitive aquatics programs and are requesting larger superpools. 
	 
Best and Final Proposal Negotiations
Strawn’s base price for design and construction of 5 superpools plus minor modernization of 2 existing pools is $11.3 million.  District staff from Capital Purchasing, Facilities and Swinerton Management met with Strawn Construction to solicit and negotiate their Best and Final Proposal, based on the verified needs of each school site and inclusion of the unsolicited alternates offered in Strawn’s proposal that decrease life cycle cost, improve functionality, and address poor existing conditions and code deficiencies outside of the base scope.  Strawn can design and construct 7 H-shaped superpools, including the selected unsolicited alternates, for $17,365,985; sufficient funds are available in the current budget.  To address the request for upsizing at Mt. Pleasant and Santa Teresa, the additional cost to enlarge those pools is as follows:
	 
SCHOOL
INCREASE SIZE 
ADDITIONAL COST
Mt. Pleasant 
2 additional competitive lanes 
$350,000 
Santa Teresa 
25 yard x 35 meter pool 
$1,185,000
	 
Site Councils at these schools have approved reallocation of their site-directed bond funding from other projects, in order to cover the additional cost of larger pools.  Funding to cover these additional costs will be from the de-funding of the following projects:  
Santa Teresa
Gymnasium Building 700 Foyer Modernization:  $1,100,000 
Tennis Courts Expansion: $850,000
Mt. Pleasant
Practice Field Renovation:  $360,000
	 
Strawn Construction’s Best and Final Proposal to design and construct new superpools at 7 school sites, including upsizing of the superpools at Mt. Pleasant and Santa Teresa, and including the unsolicited alternates that decrease life cycle cost, improve functionality, and address poor existing conditions and code deficiencies outside of the base scope is $18,900,985.
